File.Title: Topographical Organization and Relationship With Ventral Striatal Compartments of Prefrontal Corticostriatal Projections in the Rat
File.Authors: HENK W. BERENDSE, YVONNE GALIS-DE GRAAF, AND HENK J. GROENEWEGEN

Abstract.S: The anterograde tracer Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin was used to examine the topographical organization of the projections to the striatum arising from the various cytoarchitectonic subdivisions of the prefrontal cortex in the rat.
The relationship of the prefrontal cortical fibres with the compartmental organization of the ventral striatum was assessed by combining PHA-L tracing and enkephalin-immunohistochemistry.
The prefrontal cortex projects bilaterally with an ipsilateral predominance to the striatum, sparing only the lateral part of the caudate-putamen complex.
Each of the cytoarchitectonic subfields of the prefrontal cortex has a longitudinally oriented striatal terminal field that overlaps slightly with those of adjacent prefrontal areas.

The projections of the medial subdivision of the prefrontal cortex distribute to rostral and medial parts of the striatum, whereas the lateral prefrontal subdivision projects to more caudal and lateral striatal areas.
The terminal fields of the orbital prefrontal areas involve midventral and ventromedial parts of the caudate-putamen complex.
The projection of the ventral orbital area overlaps with that of the prelimbic area in the ventromedial part of the caudate-putamen.

In the shell region of the nucleus accumbens, fibres arising from the prelimbic area concentrate in areas of high cell density that are weakly enkephalin-immunoreactive, whereas fibres from the infralimbic area avoid such areas.

Rostrolaterally in the core region of the nucleus accumbens, fibres from deep layer V and layer VI of the dorsal part of the prelimbic area avoid the enkephalin-positive areas surrounding the anterior commissure and distribute in an inhomogeneous way over the intervening moderately enkephalin-immunoreactive compartment.
The other prefrontal fierents show only a preference for, but are not restricted to, the latter compartment.

In the border region between the nucleus accumbens and the ventromedial part of the caudate-putamen complex, patches of strong enkephalin immunoreactivity receive prefrontal cortical input from deep layer V and layer VI, whereas fibres from more superficial cortical layers project to the surrounding matrix.
Individual cytoarchitectonic subfields of the prefrontal cortex thus have circumscribed terminal domains in the striatum.

In combination with data on the organization of the midline and intralaminar thalamostriatal and thalamoprefrontal projections, the present results establish that the projections of the prefrontal cortical subfields converge in the striatum with those of their midline and intralaminar afferent nuclei.

The present findings further demonstrate that the relationship of the prefrontal corticostriatal fibres with the neurochemical compartments of the ventral striatum can be influenced by both the areal and the laminar origin of the cortical afferents, depending on the particular ventral striatal region under consideration.

Introduction.S: The prefrontal cortex in mammals is generally defined as the "essential cortical projection area of the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus" (Rose and Woolsey, '48; Krettek and Price, '77a; Groenewegen, '88; cf.
Uylings and Van Eden, '90).

It comprises several cytoarchitectonic subfields that are reciprocally connected with distinct segments of the mediodorsal nucleus (Leonard, '69; Krettek and Price, '77a; Beckstead, '79; Groenewegen, '88).

Since the mediodorsal nuclear subdivisions are characterized by different sets of afferents (Groenewegen, '88), each of the corresponding prefrontal cortical subfields receives a specific class of information.

The heterogeneity of the prefrontal cortex manifests itself likewise in the topographical arrangements of its efferent connections (Beckstead, '79; Reep and Winans, '82; Wyss and Sripanidkulchai, '84; Sesack et al., '89) and its afferent projections from the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei (Jones and Leavitt, '74; Berendse and Groenewegen, '91) and the amygdaloid complex (Krettek and Price, '77b; McDonald, '87).
Physiological and behavioural studies implicate the prefrontal cortex in a variety of functions, ranging from motor to autonomic (for review see Kolb, '84, '90).

In several of these studies a functional specialization of the various prefrontal subfields has been proposed (e.g., Eichenbaum et al., '83; Shipley and Geinisman, '84; Neafsey et al., '86a,b; Terreberry and Neafsey, '87).

Anatomical investigations in several mammalian species have convincingly demonstrated that functionally different cortical areas project to largely separate striatal regions (rat: Webster, '61; McGeorge and Faull, '89; rabbit: Carman et al., '63; cat: Webster, '65; Jayaraman, '85; dog: Tanaka, '79, '83, '87; Tanaka et al., '79, '81; monkey: Kemp and Powell, '70; Kunzle, '75, '77, '78; Kunzle and Akert, '77; Yeterian and Van Hoesen, '78; Van Hoesen et al., '81; Selemon and Goldman-Rakic, '85).
In contrast, the projections of functionally related cortical areas may either overlap Cyeterian and Van Hoesen, '78) or interdigitate in the same striatal region (Selemon and Goldman-Rakic, '85).

This arrangement suggests that the striatum is functionally heterogeneous, a notion substantiated by the results of physiological and behavioural studies (Winocur, '74; Oberg and Divac, '75; Rosenkilde and Divac, '76; Divac et al., '78; Dunnett and Iversen, '80, '81, '82a,b,c; Rolls and Williams, '87; Pisa, '88; Kelley et al., '88, '89; Pisa and Schranz, '88; Pisa and Cyr, '90).

On the basis of available anatomical and physiological data in the primate, Alexander et al. ('86) have tentatively identified a number of parallel circuits leading from the cerebral cortex through the basal ganglia, via the thalamus, to the frontal lobe.
Each of these circuits engages distinct parts of the cerebral cortex, the striatum, the pallidum, and the thalamus.

Most extensively studied is the so-called "motor circuit" characterized by somatotopic channels that each include subchannels, selectively subserving different aspects of motor processing (Alexander and Crutcher, '90; Alexander et al., '90).

Whether a parallel functional organization is equally explicit in the prefrontal corticostriatofugal pathways and whether it is present in species other than the primate, are as yet unanswered questions.
To resolve these issues requires a detailed knowledge of the topographical characteristics of the prefrontal corticostriatal projections and the subsequent striatopallidal and pallidothalamic links.

The striatal projections of the prefrontal cortex have previously been examined with both anterograde and retrograde tracing techniques in several species (Johnson et al., '68; Goldman and Nauta, '77; Kunzle, '78; Beckstead, '79; Room et al., '85; Arikuni and Kubota, '86; Tanaka, '87; McGeorge and Faull, '89; Sesack et al., '89).
However, a comprehensive anterograde tracing study including all subfields of the prefrontal cortex in the rat is lacking.

At another level of complexity, the striatum is typified by its compartmental organization, which is reflected in the heterogeneous distribution of virtually all histochemical markers, receptors, uptake sites, and afferent and efferent systems (Gerfen, '84, '85; Graybiel, '84, '90; Herkenham et al., '84; Penny et al., '88; Groenewegen et al., '89, '91; Voorn et al., '89).

The compartmentation of the ventral striatum, which is the portion of the striatum most directly associated with the limbic system by virtue of its hippocampal and amygdalar inputs, is different from that of the dorsal striatum for which a bicompartmental (patch/ matrix or striosomeimatrix) structure has been emphasized (Gerfen, '84, '85; Graybiel, '84, '90).

The chemoarchitecture and the organization of the afferent and efferent connections suggest that the compartmental ordering of the ventral striatum varies from one region to the other (Groenewegen et al., '89, '91; Voorn et al., '89; Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a; Berendse et al., '92).
Initially, the compartmental distribution of the corticostriatal inputs was related to the cytoarchitectonic area of origin.

The prelimbic cortex was considered to project to the patch compartment throughout the striatum, whereas the projections of the other cortical areas examined were thought to be confined to the matrix (Gerfen, '84; Donoghue and Herkenham, '86).

However, it has recently been suggested that, in addition to the areal origin, the laminar origin of the cortical fibres may influence their relationship to the patch/matrix organization of the dorsal striatum in the rat (Gerfen and Rutherford, '88; Gerfen, '89).

In the cat and the monkey, a pattern of dorsal fills and ventral avoids of striosomes within a single striatal terminal field, resulting from anterograde tracer injections in the fronto-insular cortex, has been described (Ragsdale and Graybiel, '81, '84, '90).
The main objective of the present study was to provide a detailed map of the striatal projections of the various cytoarchitectonic and possibly functionally different prefrontal cortical subfields.
Subsequent links in the prefrontal corticostriatofugal pathways, viz., the striatopallidal and pallidothalamic connections, have been analyzed in parallel studies (Groenewegen and Berendse, '90).

Furthermore, the organization of the prefrontal corticostriatal connections was compared to that of the midline and intralaminar thalamostriatal and thalamoprefrontal pathways (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a, '91) to determine whether and to what extent the projections of the midline and intralaminar nuclei converge with those of their prefrontal cortical target areas in the same striatal region.

Lastly, the relationship of the prefrontal cortical afferent fibres with the compartmental organization of the ventral striatum was assessed, with special consideration of the laminar origin of the fibres.
To these aims, small deposits of the anterograde tracer Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L; Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84) were placed at various depths in the prefrontal cortical areas.
The distribution of the opioid peptide enkephalin (ENK), visualized immunohistochemically, was used as a marker for the compartmentation of the ventral striatum (Voorn et al., '89).
Part of the present results have been reported in abstract form (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90b).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Anterograde tracing
The prefrontal corticostriatal projections were analyzed in 56 female Wistar rats (Harlan/CPB, The Netherlands), weighing 180-220 g.

Following anaesthesia with an intramuscular injection of a mixture (4/3) of ketamine and 2-(2,6-xylidine)5,6-dihydro1,3-thiazine (Rompun), in a dosage of 1 ml/kg, small deposits of PHA-L (Vector Laboratories, U.S.A.) were placed stereotaxically in the prefrontal cortex.
The coordinates were derived from the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86).

The tracer was delivered iontophoretically through glass micropipettes (external tip diameter 15-25 m) using a positive-pulsed 7.5 pA current (7 seconds on17 seconds off; CCS-3 current source, Midgard, U.S.A.) for 15-30 minutes.

Survival times ranged from 6 to 20 days, after which the animals were reanaesthetized with pentobarbital and perfused transcardially with 100 ml saline, followed by 500 ml of 4% paraformaldehyde and 0.05% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) either with or without 15% picric acid.
The brains were removed and stored in the same fixative for 1-2 hours, then transferred to a mixture of 20% glycerol and 2% dimethylsulfoxide in distilled water for overnight storage at 4°C.
Subsequently, the brains were cut on a freezing microtome at 35 pm, and the sections were collected in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).

A third, adjacent series was incubated in rabbit anti-leu-enkephalin antiserum (1:2000, Cambridge Research Biochemicals [CRB], England; 1:4000, UCB-Bioproducts [UCB-Bl, Belgium) for 18 hours at 4"C, followed by swine anti-rabbit whole serum (150) and then by rabbit-PAP (1:800 for CRB anti-enkephalin; 1:1600 for UCB-B anti-enkephalin), each for 1 hour at 20°C.
All incubations and intervening rinses were in 0.05 M Tris buffered saline (pH 7.6) with 0.5% Triton-X-100 (TBS-T).
Finally, all series were treated with DAB (50 mg in 100 ml Tris-HC1, pH 7.61, preceded by three rinses of 15 minutes each in Tris-HC1 (pH 7.6).
One of the PHA-L-stained series was counterstained with cresyl violet before coverslipping; the other series were coverslipped unstained.
The distribution of PHA-L labelled fibres and terminals was charted with the aid of a drawing tube on a standard Zeiss microscope.
Adjacent sections stained for ENK and PHA-L were used to compare the distribution patterns of PHA-L labelled fibres and ENK immunoreactivity (ENK-IR) in the ventral striatum.
Double-staining procedure
In all experiments, a fourth series of sections was processed according to a double immunoperoxidase procedure.
This procedure involves an incubation in goat anti-PHA-L antiserum (1: 1500, Vector Laboratories, U.S.A.) mixed with rabbit anti-leu-enkephalin (1:1500, CRB; 1:2500, UCB-B) for 18-66 hours at 4°C.
Subsequently, sections were treated with 1% H,O, in TBS for 10 minutes.
Sections were then incubated in a mixture of donkey anti-goat (150) and swine anti-rabbit (1:50) whole serum, for 1 hour at 20°C.

After the third incubation, in goat-PAP (1:600) for 1 hour at 20"C, sections were treated with Ni-enhanced DAB (12.5 mg DAB in 25 mlO.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4 with 1 ml 1% ammonium-Ni-sulfate), resulting in a blue-black reaction product in PHA-L labelled cells and fibres.
The final step was an incubation in rabbit-PAP (1:800 for CRB anti-enkephalin; 1: 1000 for UCB-B anti-enkephalin) and a routine-reaction with DAB.
ENK-immunoreactive structures were thus stained brown.
As in the single staining procedures, all incubations and intervening rinses were in TBS-T, whereas the DAB reactions were in Tris-HC1 (pH 7.6).

The double-staining procedure was performed on sections adjacent to those incubated either for PHA-L or for ENK, in order to enable us to compare the staining patterns of singleand double-stained sections.

To exclude the possibility of cross-reactivity between the antisera used in the double-staining procedure, and to assess the contribution of secondary and tertiary antibodies to background staining, parallel incubations were performed with various combinations of antisera, omitting one or more of the primary, secondary or tertiary antibodies.
The single immunoperoxidase reactions for PHA-L or ENK, carried out on the adjacent sections, provided us with an extra control of the specificity of the double-immunoperoxide reaction.
PHA-L antisera, that either had been pre-absorbed with rat brain tissue or had been used in prior incubations, yielded the lowest background staining.

Results.S: RESULTS

The criteria for the delineation of the various subfields of the prefrontal cortex in the rat were derived from the accounts of Krettek and Price ('77a) and Van Eden and Uylings ('85) that are based on cytoarchitectonic and hodological data.
The prefrontal cortex can be partitioned into medial, lateral or sulcal, and orbital or ventral subdivisions.
The medial subdivision comprises the infralimbic area, the prelimbic area, the anterior cingular area, and the medial precentral area.

The lateral subdivision includes the dorsal, ventral, and posterior agranular insular areas, whereas the orbital subdivision encompasses the medial orbital area, the ventral orbital area, the ventrolateral orbital area, and the lateral orbital area.
The medial precentral area of Krettek and Price ('77a) is identical to the medial agranular field of the motor cortex, as delineated by Donoghue and Parham ('83) and Reep et al. ('87).
In the present account, we will use the term medial agranular area.

The medial orbital area will be included in the medial prefrontal cortex, as it is not possible, on the basis of cytoarchitectonics, to distinguish this area from the infralimbic area with which it is caudally continuous (Van Eden and Uylings, '85).
Compartmental organization of the ventral striatum

On the basis of the distribution patterns in the ventral striatum of a number of neurochemical substances, three regions that each display a characteristic compartmental organization can be distinguished (Herkenham et al., '84; Voorn et al., '86, '89; for reviews see Groenewegen et al., '89, '91).

The distribution of the opioid peptide enkephalin, as seen in the present experimental material, is in agreement with the previous descriptions and is used in this study as the marker for the ventral striatal compartments.
In the three distinct regions mentioned above ENK-IR is distributed as follows.
In the medial and ventral parts (or shell region) of the nucleus accumbens, areas of weak ENK-IRare surrounded by moderate ENK-IR.
These areas coincide with clusters of densely packed cells and high opiate receptor binding (Herkenham et al., '84; Voorn et al., '89; Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a).
At caudal levels of the nucleus accumbens, the weakly ENK-immunoreactive areas delineate the shell region from the core region to some extent.
In the rostrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens, several large areas of strong ENK-IR stand out against a moderately stained background.
They are most conspicuous in the vicinity of the anterior commissure.

At more caudal levels, in the border region between the caudodorsal part of the nucleus accumbens and the ventral part of the caudate-putamen, smaller patches of strong ENK-IR are present within a moderately stained background.
Although the small and the above-described large areas of strong ENK-IR share a weak immunoreactivity for dopamine, a number of other neurochemical characteristics are different (Voorn et al., '89).
Injection sites
Most PHA-L deposits in the prefrontal cortex are either round or slightly ovoid in shape, with diameters ranging from 200 to 500 Fm.
Examples of injection sites are represented in Figure lA,C,E,F.
The distribution of the PHA-L deposits over the three major subdivisions of the prefrontal cortex is illustrated in Figure 2.

The laminar distribution of the projections to the homotopic contralateral cortical area correlates with the laminar location of PHA-L labelled cell bodies at the injection site (Gerfen, '89; present results), and is used as an extra means to assess the laminar origin of the prefrontal projections to the striatum.
In Figure 1A-D, examples of both superficial and deep layer injections in the prelimbic area are illustrated together with the accompanying label in the homotopic contralateral cortical area.

Injections centred in deep layer V and layer VI produce dense contralateral cortical labelling in deep layer V and layer VI and sparse labelling in layers I and 111, whereas PHA-L deposits in layers I through superficial V give rise to dense labelling of layers I and I11 and moderate labelling of layers I1 and superficial V.
In the latter cases, deep layer V and layer VI contain sparse terminating fibres amidst a multitude of passing fibres.
Fibre labelling in the striatum
All prefrontal cortical areas project bilaterally to the striatum, with an ipsilateral predominance.
The contralateral component reaches the same striatal regions and distributes according to the same pattern as the ipsilateral component.
The most ventral part of the nucleus accumbens and the olfactory tubercle do not receive a significant contralateral projection.
In other striatal areas, the density of the contralateral projections is variable and may in some cases be equal to that of the ipsilateral projections.

Although in a few cases with superficial injections in the prefrontal cortex only weak contralateral labelling was observed, we were unable to establish a consistent relationship between the density of the contralateral projection and the laminar origin of the prefrontal corticostriatal fibres.
The majority of the corticostriatal fibres penetrate the external capsule and directly enter the striatal neuropil.
Another portion of the fibres reach the striatum by way of the bundles of the internal capsule from which they emerge close to their striatal target area.
The latter pathway is taken predominantly by fibres originating from deep layer V and layer VI.
Fibres from more superficial cortical layers may also join the fibre bundles of the internal capsule, but they appear to course alongside rather than inside the bundles.

Fibres from the lateral and medial subdivisions of the prefrontal cortex, destined for the nucleus accumbens and the olfactory tubercle, often pass in a ventral direction through the deep cortical layers or the rostra1 part of the septum to directly enter these striatal areas.
In the striatum, two major types of fibres can be observed subsequent to prefrontal cortical injections.
The first type is thick and smooth and is arranged in small clusters of fibres that have the same orientation (see Figs. 6B, 8B).
These fibres generally follow the fibre bundles of the internal capsule and may gave rise to collaterals that terminate in the striatum.
They will be referred to as passing fibres.
The second type of fibre is thinner and more tortuous than the first type.
These fibres branch frequently and are set with varicosities giving them a beaded appearance (see Figs. 6B, 8B).
Terminal specializations are rare.
Fibres from the B'
lateral prefrontal cortex are more tortuous and show more terminal specializations than those arising from the medial and ventral subdivisions of the prefrontal cortex.
The en passant axonal varicosities have diameters ranging from 0.5 to 2.5 +m and are variably spaced.

Since both en passant axonal varicosities and terminal specializations observed with the PHA-L method in other systems have been demonstrated to represent the light microscopical representations of synaptic contacts (Wouterlood and Groenewegen, '851, we assume that the second fibre type makes synaptic contacts in the striatum.
Consequently, we will refer to these fibres as terminating fibres.

Support for this assumption comes from the electron microscopical observation that non-myelinated fibres in the striatum have vesicle-filled enlargements that make en passant synaptic contacts (Kemp and Powell, '71).

In general, the projections observed following PHA-L injections in the deep layers of the prefrontal cortex are more widespread than the projections seen after injections in superficial cortical layers.
The difference is most obvious in cases with PHA-L deposits in rostral parts of the prefrontal cortex.

These observations may be explained by the fact that in the rostral part of the hemisphere, due to the extreme convexity, the deep layers of the prefrontal cortex have a smaller surface area than the superficial layers.
PHA-L deposits of a given size will therefore involve a relatively larger part of a particular cortical field when placed in the deep layers.
Projections from the medial prefrontal cortex
In 35 cases, PHA-L deposits were placed at different sites in the medial subdivision of the prefrontal cortex (Fig. 2A).

Taken as a whole, this subdivision projects predominantly to rostral and medial parts of the striatum which include the rostral and medial parts of the caudate-putamen complex and the medial parts of the nucleus accumbens and olfactory tubercle.
Each of the constituent cytoarchitectonic areas has a restricted striatal terminal field that overlaps to some extent with the target area of the adjacent cortical areas.
In addition, ventral and dorsal parts of the prelimbic area have differential striatal projections.

TTE.S: Medial orbitallinfralimbic area.
In case RP-90045, the PHA-L deposit was placed dorsally in the infralimbic area, involving layers 11-V (Fig. 3).
The deposit encroaches upon the superficial layers of the ventral part of the prelimbic area.

In the striatum, a dense plexus of terminal labelling occupies the most ventromedial part of the nucleus accumbens, extending via the striatal cell-bridges into the medial two-thirds of the olfactory tubercle where most labelled fibres are found in the pyramidal cell layer (Fig. 3A-C).
In addition,a smaller number of fibres terminate more dorsally in the nucleus accumbens, concentrating in the area interposed between the anterior commissure and the lateral ventricle (Fig. 3B,C).
The latter labelling probably results from the above-mentioned involvement in the injection site of the ventral part of the prelimbic area.
In the caudate-putamen, a few fibres terminate in the area immediately adjacent to the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and in the fundus striati (Fig. 3D).
A dense terminal plexus is present in the amygdalostriatal transition zone (Fig. 3F).
The fibres from the infralimbic area avoid clusters of densely packed cells in the medial and ventral parts of the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 4A!.
An injection that primarily involves the medial orbital area (RP-89494) produces terminal labelling in approximately the same striatal areas as described above for the infralimbic area.
However, the dorsal part of the nucleus accumbens receives only very few fibres.

Instead, there is some terminal labelling in the ventromedial part of the caudate-putamen, probably as a result of the involvement of the adjacent ventral orbital area in the injection site (see following section).

Results.S: Prelimbic area, ventral injections.

TTE.S: Injections of PHA-L were placed at varying depths in the ventral part of the prelimbic area.
In case RP-89509, the tracer deposit almost exclusively involves deep layer V and layer VI (Fig. 5).
Caudally, the injection site encroaches upon the infralimbic area.
The termination pattern in the striatum is distinctly inhomogeneous.

Rostrally in the nucleus accumbens, small offsets of PHA-L labelled fibres occupy the medial half of the nucleus (Fig. 5B), whereas, at more caudal levels, most fibres terminate in the medial part of the shell region (Fig. 5 0 .

The aggregates of PHA-L labelled fibres overlie areas of high cell density in cresyl violet-counterstained sections and coincide with areas of weak ENK-IR in adjacent sections stained for ENK (Fig. 4B-D).
Fibre concentrations of similar dimensions characterize the terminal labelling in the border region between the nucleus accumbens and the caudate-putamen (Fig. 5B,C).
They coincide with patches of strong ENK-IR both in adjacent and double-stained sections (Fig. 6A-C).
A few fibres reach the ventromedial part of the nucleus accumbens and the medial part of the olfactory tubercle, including the interconnecting cellbridges (Fig. 5A-C).
Sporadic terminating fibres are present caudal to the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 5D-F).

An injection of PHA-L that predominantly involves the superficial layers of the ventral part of the prelimbic area (case RP-89552) produces terminal labelling in approximately the same striatal regions as the injections in the deep layers.
The terminal labelling in the caudate-putamen complex extends somewhat more dorsally and caudally in a narrow strip adjacent to the lateral ventricle.
In the dorsomedial part of the nucleus accumbens, the inhomogeneously distributed terminating fibres concentrate in areas of weak ENK-IR, just as in the previous case (RP-89509).
Contrary to case RP-89509, PHA-L labelled fibres in the border zone between the nucleus accumbens and the caudate-putamen tend to avoid the patches of strong ENK-IR (Fig. 6D).

Results.S: Prelimbic area, dorsal injections.

TTE.S: Tracer injections placed dorsally in the prelimbic area produce terminal labelling predominantly in the caudate-putamen complex.
In case RP-89590, the PHA-L injection is centered in layers I1 through superficial V, with minor involvement of deep layer V (Figs. lA, 7).

At rostral striatal levels, a dense plexus of terminating fibres, interrupted by small areas almost devoid of fibres, occupies the medial half of the caudate-putamen and extends into the dorsolateral and central parts of the nucleus accumbens (Figs. 7A,B; 8A).
Caudal parts of the nucleus accumbens are very sparsely labelled (Fig. 7C).

The anterograde label in the rostral part of the caudate-putamen does not involve the most dorsal part of this nuclear complex and, additionally, spares the extreme medial rim bordering the lateral ventricle.
At the level of the major island of Calleja, the labelling in the caudate-putamen is restricted to its medial one-fourth (Fig. 7C).
Caudal to the nucleus accumbens, the labelling is much more sparse and occupies only a very small ventromedial area (Fig. 7D,E).
The most caudal part of the caudateputamen does not contain a significant amount of terminal labelling (Fig. 7F).
Fibres from the superficial layers of the dorsal prelimbic area avoid the small patches of strong ENK-IR in the border region between the nucleus accumbens and the caudate-putamen (Fig. 9A,B).
Rostrolaterally in the nucleus accumbens, the majority of the fibres terminate outside the ENK-positive areas, a small number of fibres terminating within these areas (Fig. 9C,D).

Following PHA-L injections centred in deep layer V and layer VI of the dorsal part of the prelimbic area (e.g., case RP-89474; Fig. 10, the terminal labelling occupies the same striatal regions as the labelling produced by superficially placed injections.
The distribution pattern is characterized by small aggregates of fibres surrounded by unlabelled areas (Fig. 8B; cf Fig. 8A).
These aggregates overlap with the small patches of strong ENK-IR in the border region between the nucleus accumbens and the caudateputamen (Fig. 6E).
In the rostrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens, PHA-L labelled fibres avoid the large areas of strong ENK-IR (Fig. 6F).
Interestingly, they are inhomogeneously distributed over the moderately ENK-immunoreactive compartment.

In most cases, in which the tracer deposit involves the deep layers of the dorsal prelimbic area, additional sparse label is present in the extreme dorsal part of the caudomedial shell area of the nucleus accumbens.
This label overlies areas of low ENK-IR and high cell density.
Ventral anterior cingular area.
In case RP-90278, a PHA-L injection is centred in the ventral anterior cingular area (Fig. 10D).
The deposit primarily involves layers 11,111, and superficial V.
The resulting terminal labelling is most dense at rostra1 striatal levels and occupies the dorsomedial part of the caudate-putamen.
The labelled fibres are arranged in several bands that extend in a lateral direction from the lateral ventricle (Figs. 8C, 11D).
Caudal to the nucleus accumbens, only a small number of fibres occupy the medial part of the caudate-putamen.

PHA-L injections that predominantly involve deep layer V and layer VI of the ventral anterior cingular area produce a patchy pattern of terminal label in the dorsomedial part of the striatum (Fig. 8D).

Results.S: Dorsal anterior cingular arealmedial agranular area.

TTE.S: The PHA-L deposit in case RP-90216 is centred in the supragenual part of the dorsal anterior cingular area (Fig. 10B).
The distinctly inhomogeneous terminal field is largely confined to the dorsal part of the caudate-putamen and appears to be arranged in a number of bands that are mediolaterally oriented (Fig. 11B).
The label occupies a slightly more lateral position compared to that observed following ventral anterior cingular injections (case RP90278; cf Fig. 11B,D).
At the level of the globus pallidus, only a few fibres terminate in the medial part of the caudate-putamen.
The PHA-L deposit in case RP-90315 is largely restricted to the superficial layers of the supragenual part of the medial agranular area (Fig. 10A).
The fibre labelling in the striatum occupies a more lateral position in comparison to that found in the previous case (RP-90216) and is confined to the caudate-putamen.
The density of fibres is highest at intermediate rostrocaudal levels.
Rostrally in the caudate-putamen, most fibres terminate in a dorsolateral strip immediately underneath the external capsule, whereas a few fibres terminate more centrally (Fig. 11A).
In the caudal part of the caudate-putamen, the density of the centrally located labelling equals that of the dorsolateral strip.
Labelled fibres reach the caudal extreme of the caudate-putamen complex.

PHA-L injections centred in the deep layers of the supragenual parts of the dorsal anterior cingular and medial agranular areas produce only very scant label in dorsal and central parts of the caudate-putamen.

Results.S: The labelled fibres are arranged in clusters.

TTE.S: Injections placed in the pregenual parts of the dorsal anterior cingular or the medial agranular areas result in a pattern of labelling that involves largely the same mediolateral striatal regions as in the cases with supragenually placed injections.
However, the highest density of labelled fibres in the former cases is found more ventrally and rostrally in the striatum.
In case RP-90091, a PHA-L deposit is centred in layer V of the pregenual parts of the dorsal anterior cingular and medial agranular areas (Figs.
Rostrally in the striatum, the terminal label occupies the lateral two-thirds of the caudate-putamen and extends into the rostrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 12A,B).
At the level of the major island of Calleja, the label is restricted to a central region in the dorsal part of the caudate-putamen, with sparse labelling dorsolateral to it (Figs. 11C; 12C,D).
Caudally, the fibres concentrate in two bands, one adjacent to the external capsule and the other more ventrally in the medial part of the caudateputamen complex (Fig. 12E).
In the rostrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens, most fibres coming from the pregenual parts of the dorsal anterior cingular and medial agranular areas avoid the large areas of strong ENK-IR.

Results.S: Projections from the lateral prefrontal cortex
The lateral prefrontal cortex was the target of 13 PHA-L injections (Fig. 2B).
Lateral prefrontal cortical injections typically result in more laterally located terminal label in the striatum than in the cases of medial prefrontal injections.
Two cases with PHA-L deposits in the ventral and dorsal subfields of the agranular insular area will be considered in detail.

TTE.S: Following a PHA-L injection in the posterior agranular insular area (RP-90474; Fig. 2B) only very weak labelling in the lateral part of the nucleus accumbens was observed.

Results.S: Ventral agranular insular area.

TTE.S: A deposit of PHA-L centred in layer V of the ventral agranular insular area (case RP-89374; Fig. 131, with some involvement of layers I11 and VI, results in a rather restricted terminal field in the striatum.
Labelled fibres terminate predominantly in the ventrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens, the adjacent lateral part of the olfactory tubercle, and the interconnecting cell-bridges (Fig. 13A-C).
A modest amount of terminal labelling occupies the fundus striati and the midventral part of the caudate-putamen at intermediate rostrocaudal levels (Fig. 13C-E).
In the latter area, passing fibres are more numerous than terminating fibres.
In the ventral part of the nucleus accumbens, the fibres tend to avoid clusters of densely packed cells.

Results.S: Dorsal agranular insular area.

TTE.S: In case RP-89397, a PHA-L injection was placed dorsally in the caudal part of the dorsal agranular insular area (Fig. 14).
MostPHA-L labelled neurons lie in layers 11, 111, and superficial V, whereas deep layer V and layer VI are only slightly involved.
In the striatum, fibres terminate laterally in the core region of the nucleus accumbens and in the ventral and ventrolatera1 parts of the caudate-putamen complex (Fig. 14B,C).
The terminal field consists of a densely labelled zone with intervening areas of sparse or absent fibre labelling.
Caudal to the nucleus accumbens, PHA-L labelled fibres in the caudate-putamen occupy a more medial position (Fig. 14D,E).

A more ventrally placed superficial PHA-L deposit (case RP-89375) produces terminal labelling that is most dense in more rostra1 and medial parts of the core of the nucleus accumbens and in a ventromedial sector of the caudate-putamen.
Due to the involvement in this case of the ventral agranular insular area in the injection site, fibre labelling is present in the areas described for case RP-89374 as well.

Results.S: In the border region between the nucleus accumbens and the adjacent ventromedial part of the caudate-putamen, the restricted blank areas within the dense plexus of terminating fibres coming from the superficial layers of the dorsal agranular insular area coincide with patches of strong ENK-IR (Fig. 15A,B).

In the ventrolateral part of the caudate-putamen, fibres originating from PHA-L deposits that mainly involve layers I1 to superficial V of the caudal part of the dorsal agranular insular area (cases RP-89376 and RP-89397) distribute more densely to patches of strong ENK-IR than to the surrounding areas.

However, more rostrally placed injections, the centres of which are located more superficially such that involvement of the deeper layers can be excluded (e.g., case RP-895241, produce a pattern of avoidance of the zones of strong ENK-IR in the ventrolateral part of the caudate-putamen (Fig. 16A,B).

TTE.S: A PHA-L injection in the same part of the dorsal agranular insular area as in case RP-89397, but involving predominantly deep layer V and layer VI (case RP-89398; Fig. lE), labels approximately the same striatal regions.
However, in case RP-89398, small fibre concentrations of variable size are surrounded by more sparsely labelled areas.
In the border region between the nucleus accumbens and the ventromedial part of the caudate-putamen, these fibre aggregates overlap extensively with patches of strong ENK-IR (Fig. 17A).
A similar relationship exists in the ventrolateral part of the caudate-putamen complex (Fig. 16C,D).

In a few cases with caudally placed injections in either the deep or the superficial layers of the dorsal agranular insular area, PHA-L labelled fibres are present in the rostrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens.
They terminate both in and outside the large areas of strong ENK-IR that surround the anterior commissure, but the density of labelling is highest outside these areas (Fig. 15C,D).

Results.S: Projections from the orbital prefrontal cortex

TTE.S: In 8 cases, PHA-L deposits were placed in the orbital subfields of the prefrontal cortex (Fig. 2B).
All of these injections result in a terminal plexus that is largely restricted to the ventral part of the caudate-putamen.
The medial-to-lateral gradient in the orbital prefrontal cortex is maintained in the projections to the striatum.

Results.S: Ventral orbital area.

TTE.S: The injection of PHA-L in case RP-90404 is largely restricted to layers 11,111, and superficial V of the ventral orbital area(Figs. lF, 18).
A small number of PHA-L labelled neurons in the deep layers of the cortex of the frontal pole cannot be attributed to any particular cortical area.
The resulting terminal plexus in the striatum is largely confined to the caudate-putamen where it occupies a ventromedial region adjacent to the lateral ventricle (Fig. 18).
This plexus extends throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the caudate-putamen and is most dense at intermediate levels (Fig. 18B-F).
Several circumscribed unlabelled areas within the terminal plexus coincide with patches of strong ENK-IR (Fig. 17B).
A small amount of terminal labelling is present rostrally in the olfactory tubercle and in the ventrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 18A-C).

Results.S: Ventrolateral orbital area.

TTE.S: Injections in the ventrolatera1 orbital area produce very sparse fibre labelling centrally in the caudate-putamen complex.
Lateral orbital area.
The PHA-L deposit in case RP89363 predominantly involves layers 11,111, and superficial V of the lateral orbital area (Fig. 19).
The resulting terminal label is distinctly inhomogeneous and is located centrally in the caudate-putamen at intermediate rostrocaudal levels (Fig. 19C,D).
Caudally, labelled fibres shift to a more dorsal and medial position (Fig. 19E).

In addition to the terminal plexus in the caudate-putamen, there is sparse terminal label in the ventrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens, the lateral part of the olfactory tubercle, and the fundus striati (Fig. 19A-D).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

In line with previous reports, the results of the present anterograde tracing study in the rat demonstrate that the prefrontal cortex projects bilaterally to the striatum, sparing only the lateral part of the caudate-putamen complex (Beckstead, '79; McGeorge and Faull, '89; Sesack et al., '89).

Moreover, our results confirm that the prefrontal corticostriatal projection is topographically organized (Johnson et al., '68; Beckstead, '79; Reep and Winans, '82; McGeorge and Faull, '89; Sesack et al., '89).

However, due to the placement of PHA-L deposits throughout the prefrontal cortex, a more detailed map of the projections from the various cytoarchitectonic, and possibly functionally different, prefrontal cortical subfields to the striatum could be provided.
In particular, the organization of the projections to the ventral striatum has been clarified.
Furthermore, it could be demonstrated that the topography of the prefrontal corticostriatal projections is maintained within a given cortical area.

In combination with our data on the organization of the midline and intralaminar projections to the prefrontal cortex (Berendse and Groenewegen, '91) and the striatum (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a), the present results show that the projections of individual prefrontal cortical areas converge in the striatum with those of their midline and intralaminar afferent nuclei.
Last and perhaps most important, the present account describes the relationship of the prefrontal cortical afferent fibres with the ventral striatal compartments.
Throughout most of the ventral striatum, the laminar origin of the cortical fibres is the major factor determining their relationship with the compartments (cf.
Gerfen and Rutherford, '88; Gerfen, '89).
In contrast, in the shell region of the nucleus accumbens, the areal origin appears to be more important.
Methodological considerations

The use of the PHA-L tracing technique offers many advantages when studying in detail the organization of projections in small experimental animals (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84; Groenewegen and Wouterlood, '90).
However, potential drawbacks of the method are the uptake of PHA-L by fibres of passage (Cliffer and Giesler, '88; Schofield, '90) and the retrograde transport of PHA-L (Shu and Peterson, '88).

In the present experiments, injections restricted to deep cortical layers, through which fibres from more superficial layers course towards the subcortical white matter, result in a projection pattern in the striatum that is quite different from that observed after more superficial PHA-L injections.
Therefore, it is quite unlikely that uptake of PHA-L by fibres of passage is a confounding factor in the present study.
Retrograde neuronal labelling was limited to an occasional cortical neuron at some distance from the injection site.
Topographical organization of prefrontal corticostriatal projections
The organization of the prefrontal corticostriatal projections is illustrated in Figure 20.
Each of the various cytoarchitectonic subfields of the prefrontal cortex has a quite restricted terminal field in the striatum.

Although it is likely that the projections from other cortical areas will, in some parts of the striatum, overlap with those of the prefrontal cortex (McGeorge and Faull, '89), there appears to be only a limited degree of overlap between the projections of adjacent prefrontal areas.
The precise extent of the overlap can only be determined by means of double anterograde tracing.
The medial subdivision of the prefrontal cortex projects predominantly to rostral and medial parts of the caudateputamen complex, the nucleus accumbens, and the olfactory tubercle (cf.
Beckstead, '79; McGeorge and Faull, '89; Sesack et al., '89).

The lateral subdivision of the prefrontal cortex issues fibres to the ventral part of the caudateputamen complex, the central and lateral parts of the nucleus accumbens, and the lateral part of the olfactory tubercle (cf.
Within the projections of the medial and lateral prefrontal subdivisions, a ventral-todorsal gradient in the cortex corresponds to a ventromedialto-dorsolateral gradient in the striatum.
The orbital or ventral subdivision of the prefrontal cortex projects to the midventral and ventromedial parts of the caudate-putamen (Beckstead, '79; McGeorge and Faull, '89).
The projections of the orbital subdivision are topographically organized along a mediolateral axis.
The terminal zones in the striatum of the ventral and ventrolateral orbital areas overlap with those of the prelimbic and anterior cingular areas (compare Figs. 18 and 20).

The present results demonstrate that the projections of the medial orbital and infralimbic cortical areas reach identical striatal areas, viz., the most ventromedial part of the nucleus accumbens, the medial two-thirds of the olfactory tubercle, and the amygdalostriatal transition zone (Fig. 20).

Taking together the similarities in cytoarchitecture (Van Eden and Uylings, '851, thalamic afferents (Berendse and Groenewegen, '9 11, and striatal efferents (present results), it can be argued that the medial orbital and infralimbic areas should be considered as a single cortical field.

If the presence of projections from the mediodorsal nucleus is a prerequisite for the inclusion of a particular cortical area in the prefrontal cortex, the medial orbital and infralimbic areas should not be denoted as prefrontal (Krettek and Price, '77a; Groenewegen, '88).

However, since the projections from the parataenial thalamic nucleus to both areas (Krettek and Price, '77a; Berendse and Groenewegen, '91) seem to be comparable to those of the mediodorsal nucleus to the prefrontal cortex, the medial orbital and infralimbic areas are here included in the prefrontal cortex.

Considering the projections of the prelimbic area as a whole, the present findings are in agreement with those of previous anterograde and retrograde tracing studies (Beckstead, '79; Room et al., '85; McGeorge and Faull, '89; Sesack et al., '89).
Although the prelimbic area is cytoarchitonically homogeneous, differential striatal projections were found for its ventral versus its dorsal part (Fig. 20).

The former issues fibres predominantly to the medial part of the nucleus accumbens and the adjoining, most ventromedial portion of the caudate-putamen, whereas, the latter projects densely to a medial sector of the caudate-putamen and, at rostral levels, to central and dorsolateral parts of the nucleus accumbens.
Deep layer V and layer VI of the dorsal part of the prelimbic area project in addition to the most dorsomedial part of the shell of the nucleus accumbens.
Similar dorsoventral differences in the corticofugal connections have been reported earlier for the rostral part of the prelimbic area (Sesack et al., '89).
The present results demonstrate that this differentiation holds for the entire prelimbic area.

In view of the differential inputs from the paraventricular and central medial thalamic nuclei to the ventral versus the dorsal part of the prelimbic area, and to their respective striatal target zones (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a, '91) it is tempting to suggest that the prelimbic area is functionally heterogeneous.

The observations that only the ventral part of the prelimbic area projects to brainstem autonomic centres (Terreberry and Neafsey, '83, '87; Neafsey et al., '86b) and receives projections from the CA1 field of the hippocampus and the subiculum (Jay and Witter, '91) lend additional support to this assumption.

The present results confirm the differences between the striatal projections of the anterior cingular and medial agranular areas (Beckstead, '79; Veening et al., '80; Kubozono et al., '86; Reep et al., '87; McGeorge and Faull, '89; Sesack et al., '89; Tehovnik et al., '89).
Presently, these projections could be further differentiated.
First, the ventral and dorsal subfields of the anterior cingular area were found to have differential projections (Fig. 20).
Furthermore, rostrocaudal differences were observed within the projections of both the dorsal anterior cingular and the medial agranular areas.
Rostra1 (pregenual) parts of these areas project ventrally and rostrally within the striatum, whereas the fibres from caudal (supragenual) parts terminate in more dorsal and caudal striatal regions.
A similar pattern is apparent when the projections of the ventral part of the anterior cingular area are compared with those of the rostrally adjacent, dorsal part of the prelimbic area.
Consistent with the report by Reep and Winans ('82) in the hamster, we found differential striatal projections for the ventral and dorsal agranular insular areas (see also McGeorge and Faull, '89).

However, our data indicate that, in the rat, the terminal field of the ventral agranular insular area is restricted to the most ventrolateral parts of the nucleus accumbens and olfactory tubercle, and that the striatal projection of the dorsal subfield includes part of the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 20; cf.
Reep and Winans, '82).

The fibre labelling we observed in the midventral part of the caudate-putamen, following an injection in the ventral agranular insular area, most probably is the result of involvement in the injection site of the rostrally adjacent lateral orbital area.

Consistent with this interpretation, the lateral orbital area, but not the ventral agranular insular area, displays labelled cells following retrograde tracer injections in the caudate-putamen (McGeorge and Faull, '89).

Conversely, the sparse terminal label that was observed in the ventrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens, the lateral part of the olfactory tubercle, and the fundus striati, in cases with injections in the lateral orbital area, probably results from the involvement in the injection site of the caudally adjacent ventral agranular insular area.
The present study is the first to describe the topography in the projections from the orbital subdivision of the prefrontal cortex to the ventral part of the caudate-putamen (cf.
Beckstead, '79).
Parallel arrangement of basal ganglia-thalamocortical circuits

Previously, we have described the topographical organization of the projections from the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei to both the striatum and the cerebral cortex (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a, '91).

A comparison of the organization of these projections with that of the prefrontal corticostriatal projections reveals that the projections from interconnected parts of the prefrontal cortex and the midline and intralaminar nuclear complex converge in the same part of the striatum.
For instance, the intermediodorsal thalamic nucleus projects both to the caudal part of the core region of the nucleus accumbens and to the dorsal agranular insular area.
The latter cortical area projects to the caudal part of the accumbal core as well (present results).
A similar arrangement has been described in Tupaza for the afferents from the pulvinar and the visual cortex to the caudal part of the putamen (Matelli et al., '88).

Since the pathways from the striatum via the pallidum and the thalamus back to the prefrontal cortex are also characterized by a high degree of segregation (Groenewegen, '88; Groenewegen and Berendse, '90; Groenewegen et al., 'goal, the available anatomical data indicate that, in the rat, the prefrontal cortex, the related parts of the midline and intralaminar nuclei and their striatal targets, are involved in multiple parallel circuits that lead via the basal ganglia back to the prefrontal cortex.
Specific parts of the basolatera1 amygdaloid nucleus may be differentially involved in such circuits (Groenewegen et al., '90a).

Thus, the concept of a parallel organization of basal forebrain circuitry, as originally suggested by Alexander et al. ('86, '90) in the primate, is strengthened and can be broadened to include the projections of the midline and intralaminar nuclear complex to both the striatum and the prefrontal cortex.

The fact that the projections from the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclear complex to the cortex fit in with this organization, leads us to speculate that a parallel arrangement of connections is not restricted to basal ganglia circuitry, but may represent a more general characteristic of forebrain connections.

Our findings therefore support the ideas put forward by Goldman-Rakic ('88) based on the existence of several parallel networks of corticocortical connections that process distinct classes of information.
Contralateral prefrontal corticostriatal projections
In our experiments, the contralateral projections to the most ventral parts of the nucleus accumbens and to the olfactory tubercle were minimal.
In other striatal areas, the contralateral projections were generally less dense than the ipsilateral projections, but in a few cases both components had equal densities.

Although superficially placed PHA-L deposits tend to result in less dense contralateral labelling of the striatum, it is not possible to establish an unequivocal relationship between the laminar origin of the cortical afferents and the density of the contralateral projections in the present material.

Previous studies by means of retrograde tracing techniques have shown that the projections to the contralateral striatum originate exclusively from layers I11 and superficial V (Wilson, '87; McGeorge and Faull, '89).

In contrast, the results of our experiments demonstrate that injections of PHA-L restricted to deep layer V and layer VI produce bilateral labelling of the striatum and, in addition, of the corresponding layers of the contralateral homotopic cortical area.

Moreover, in experiments in which injections of the sensitive retrograde tracer choleratoxin subunit B were placed in various parts of the nucleus accumbens, the density of label in the deep layers of the contralateral prefrontal cortex equals that of the ipsilateral side (unpublished observations).
These results strongly suggest that crossed corticostriatal neurons are present in deep layer V and layer VI as well.
Crossed corticostriatal neurons do not respond to stimulation of the ipsilateral cerebral peduncle or thalamus (Wilson, '86, '87).

Therefore, unless in the latter experiments the placement of the recording electrodes was biased towards neurons in the superficial cortical layers, it is unlikely that the crossed corticostriatal neurons in the deep layers of the cerebral cortex are identical to neurons projecting to the brainstem or thalamus.
Relationship of prefrontal cortical fibres with ventral striatal compartments
Figure 21 summarizes the compartmental relationships of the prefrontal corticostriatal fibres.
In each of the three previously defined regions of the ventral striatum (see Results) these relationships are different.

Therefore, the present results again emphasize that, contrary to the situation in the dorsal striatum (see Gerfen, '84, '85; Graybiel, '84, 'go), the ventral striatum has a compartmental ordering that varies from one region to the other (Voorn et al., '89; for reviews see Groenewegen et al., '89, '91).

Within each of the three ventral striatal regions considered, the differential input-output characteristics of the compartments permit specific sets of cortical and thalamic inputs to interact with neurons projecting to distinct targets in the mesencephalon (Groenewegen et al., '87; Berendse et al., '88, '92; Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a; present results).

The present results show that, throughout the shell region of the nucleus accumbens, fibres from the ventral part of the prelimbic area concentrate inside areas of high cell density and weak ENK-IR (Fig. 21).

Since the cell clusters in the nucleus accumbens coincide with opiate receptor patches (Herkenham et al., '84), the present results confirm and extend the observation of Donoghue and Herkenham ('86) that prelimbic cortical fibres in the caudomedial part of the nucleus accumbens overlie opiate receptor patches.
It could furthermore be established that both deep and superficial layers of the ventral prelimbic area project to the cell clusters.
The deep layers of the dorsal part of the prelimbic area issue fibres towards the most dorsomedial cell clusters only.
Contrary to the fibres from the prelimbic area, fibres from the infralimbic area avoid the cell clusters.
Thus, in the shell region of the nucleus accumbens, the areal origin of the fibres seems to be more important than their laminar origin in determining the compartmental relationships.

The neurons in the shell region of the striatum that project to the ventral mesencephalon are located outside the cell clusters (Berendse et al., '921, and therefore lie in the compartment receiving afferents from the infralimbic cortex, the midline thalamic nuclei, and the ventral subiculum (Herkenham et al., '84; Groenewegen et al., '87; Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a; present results).
The same afferents may also establish contacts with neurons inside the cell clusters, as their dendrites extend up to 50-100 km outside the clusters (Herkenham et al., '84).
Unfortunately, our current knowledge of the output of these clusters of small cells is limited to the observation that they do not project to the ventral mesencephalon (Berendse et al., '90).
Unpublished observations indicate that neurons inside as well as outside the cell clusters project to the ventral pallidum.
The projections of different parts of the amygdaloid complex either selectively innervate or avoid the cell clusters (Groenewegen et al., '91).

In the border region between the nucleus accumbens and the ventral part of the caudate-putamen, the laminar origin of the prefrontal afferent fibres determines their relationship with the small patches of ENK-IR.
Fibres originating in layers I1 through superficial V avoid the patches, whereas fibres arising from deep layer V and layer VI selectively terminate inside the patches (Fig. 21).

Since the patches of ENK-IR in this part of the striatum coincide with patches of weak calbindin D28ku-IR (Voorn et al., '89), the present findings confirm the observations by Gerfen ('89) that the laminar origin of fibres from the medial prefrontal cortex determines their relationship to patches of weak calbindin DL,,,-IR.

The present results further indicate that, in the border region between the nucleus accumbens and the caudate-putamen, the compartmental relationships of fibres from the lateral and orbital subdivisions of the prefrontal cortex are similar to those of fibres from the medial prefrontal cortex (Fig. 21).

Fibres originating in layers I1 through superficial V of both the lateral and orbital prefrontal subdivisions avoid patches of strong ENK-IR within their terminal field, whereas fibres from deep layer V and layer VI of the lateral prefrontal subdivision terminate inside the patches.
Since none of our PHA-L deposits were confined to the deep layers of the orbital subfields, we can only speculate that the deep layers of these subfields project to the patches of strong ENK-IR.

Considering the abovedescribed data, it would seem that, at least in some parts of the striatum, the ontogenetically older, deep layers of the prefrontal cortex project to the older patch compartment, whereas younger, more superficial layers are related to the younger matrix compartment (Fishell and van der Kooy, '87; van der Kooy and Fishell, '87; Bayer, '90).

In this respect, it is interesting to note that the paraventricular thalamic nucleus, which projects to the patches of ENK-IR in the ventromedial part of the caudate-putamen and the dorsal part of the nucleus accumbens (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a), sends fibres to deep layer V and layer VI of the dorsal part of the prelimbic area (Berendse and Groenewegen, '91).

The other midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei that send fibres to the striatal neuropil surrounding the ENK-patches (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a), project to superficial layer V and layer I of this prefrontal area (Berendse and Groenewegen, '91 J.

Although conclusive evidence can only be provided by means of electron microscopy, these findings seem to indicate that in the border region of the nucleus accumbens and the caudate-putamen, both the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei, and the cortical neurons most directly influenced by these thalamic nuclei, project to the same striatal Compartment.

Recent observations indicate that the great majority of the ventral striatal neurons projecting to the ventral mesencephalon have a dendritic tree that is confined to the compartment in which the parent cell body resides (Groenewegen et al., '90b; cf.
Penny et al., '88).

Therefore, fibres from the deep layers of the prefrontal cortex may selectively contact neurons projecting to the substantia nigra pars compacta, whereas fibres from more superficial layers may reach neurons innervating the pars reticulata (Gerfen, '84, '85, '89; Berendse et al., '92).

In the rostrolateral part of the nucleus accumbens, fibres coming from the deep layers of the prelimbic area distribute in an inhomogeneous way over the moderately ENKimmunoreactive compartment (Fig. 21).

Since the neurons that project to the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra pars compacta are located in the latter compartment (Groenewegen et al., '89, '91; Berendse et al., '92), only the afferents from the deep layers of the prelimbic area may be selectively related to these neurons.

This is even more likely in view of the fact that, also in this ventral striatal region, the dendritic tree of neurons projecting to the mesencephalon is confined to the compartment in which the cell body resides (Groenewegen et al., '90b).

The other prefrontal afferents show only a preference for, but are not restricted to, the moderately ENK-immunoreactive compartment and may therefore additionally contact neurons projecting to the substantia nigra pars reticulata (Berendse et al., '92).

In addition to the above-mentioned clustering of fibres from the deep layers of the medial prefrontal cortex within a single neurochemical striatal compartment, patterns of dense versus extremely dense labelling occur within the termination fields of the superficial cortical layers.
This type of arrangement suggests the presence of additional compartments in the striatum (cf.

Malach and Graybiel, '86; Jimenez-Castellanos and Graybiel, '89; GimenezAmaya and Graybiel, '90) or, alternatively, indicates that the inhomogeneities are related to a columnar organization in the cerebral cortex.
Differences in the density of striatal labelling could thus be explained by a variable involvement of adjacent columns by a single tracer injection.

In cats and monkeys, a pattern of dorsal fills and ventral avoids of the striosomal compartment was reported following large injections of tritiated amino acids in the frontoinsular cortex (Ragsdale and Graybiel, '81, '84, '90).

It is unclear to what extent this pattern is comparable to the differential relationships of prelimbic cortical fibres with ENK-positive areas in different striatal sectors, observed in the present study.
More likely, the pattern is caused by the differential involvement of cortical layers in adjacent cortical columns.
Functional considerations

An overall topographical organization of corticostriatal projections has been demonstrated previously in several species (rat: Webster, '61; McGeorge and Faull, '89; rabbit: Carman et al., '63; cat: Webster, '65; Jayaraman, '85; dog: Tanaka, '79, '83, '87; Tanaka et al., '79, '81; monkey: Kemp and Powell, '70; Kunzle, '75, '77, '78; Kunzle and Akert, '77; Yeterian and Van Hoesen, '78; Van Hoesen et al., '81; Seiemon and Goldman-Rakic, '85).
Thus, functionally different cortical regions have, at least to some degree, separate projection fields in the striatum.

This arrangement indicates that the striatum is functionally heterogeneous, which is in agreement with the results of physiological and behavioural studies (Winocur, '74; Oberg and Divac, '75; Rosenkilde and Divac, '76; Divac et al., '78; Dunnett and Iversen, '80, '81, '82a,b,c; Rolls and Williams, '87; Pisa, '88; Kelley et al., '88, '89; Pisa and Schranz, '88; Pisa and Cyr, '90).

The presently observed detailed topographical organization of the projections from the prefrontal cortex to the striatum may therefore be considered as the anatomical substrate for an even more fine-grained functional heterogeneity of those parts of the striatum that receive prefrontal cortical afferents.

The above-discussed convergence in the striatum of afferents from parts of the prefrontal cortex and the midline, and intralaminar thalamic nuclear complex that are interconnected, as well as the degree of segregation in the subsequent striatopallidal, pallidothalamic (Groenewegen and Berendse, '90; Groenewegen et al., '90a) and mediodorsal-prefrontal (Groenewegen, '88) pathways, lend further support to this assumption.

In order to define the functional attributes of the anatomical circuits involving the prefrontal cortex in the rat, a detailed knowledge of the functions in which individual cytoarchitectonic prefrontal cortical areas and single midline and intralaminar nuclei are involved is a prerequisite.

In spite of the fact that many different functions have been ascribed to the prefrontal cortex (for review see Kolb, '84, 'go), the information on functional specialization of individual subfields is still fragmentary.
The infralimbic area and the ventral part of the prelimbic area are considered to function as visceral motor cortical regions, involved in the control of a variety of autonomic functions.
They project directly to autonomic centres of the brainstem, including the nucleus of the solitary tract (Terreberry and Neafsey, '83, '87; van der Kooy et al., '84; Neafsey et al., '86b).

Moreover, stimulation of these cortical areas results in changes in heart rate, blood pressure, and gastric motility (Terreberry and Neafsey, '84; Hurley-Gius and Neafsey, '86; Hardy and Holmes, '88).

Other brain areas involved in cardiovascular andlor respiratory responses, such as the paraventricular thalamic nucleus, project to the infralimbic and/or ventral prelimbic areas (Ruit and Neafsey, '88, '90; Buchanan et al., '89; Jay and Witter, '91).
The functions of more dorsal parts of the medial prefrontal cortex, viz., the dorsal part of the prelimbic area, the anterior cingular area, and the medial agranular area, are rather diverse.

The medial agranular area, particularly its rostra1 part, is generally considered as the rodent homologue of the frontal eye field, with additional supplementary motor and premotor characteristics (Hall and Lindholm, '74; Neafsey et al., '86a,b; Reep et al., '87).

Furthermore, lesions of both the medial agranular and anterior cingular area induce contralateral neglect (Cowey and Bozek, '74; Crowne et al., '83; Kolb, '84; Corwin et al., '86; Vargo et al., '88; Christie et al., '90).
Last, the medial wall of the hemisphere appears to be involved in spatial tasks and blood pressure control (Eichenbaum et al., '83; Kolb, '84, '90; Burns and Wyss, '85; Verberne et al., '87).

The connections of the agranular insular area suggest that it takes part in the regulation of visceral processes (Saper, '82; van der Kooy et al., '84; Terreberry and Neafsey, '87; Ruggiero et al., '87; Krushel and van der Kooy, '88).

It has been suggested that, contrary to the infralimbic and ventral prelimbic areas which are involved in visceral motor functions (see above), the agranular insular area participates in visceral sensory processes only (Saper, '82; Terreberry and Neafsey, '87).

More specifically, gustatory (Saper, '82; Shipley and Geinisman, '84; Kosar et al., '86a,b) and olfactory (Price and Slotnick, '83; Eichenbaum et al., '83) functions are subserved by this prefrontal area.
Cardiovascular effects of stimulation of the agranular insular area have also been reported (Buchanan and Powell, '87; Ruggiero et al., '87; Hardy and Holmes, '88).
The functional characteristics of the orbital areas of the prefrontal cortex have as yet not been elucidated in any detail.
Some of the subfields may be involved in olfactory functions (Price and Slotnick, '83; Eichenbaum et al., '83) or in agression and feedingidrinking behaviours (Reep, '84).

The above-described functional differentiation in the prefrontal cortex, though at present rather crude, should be parallelled by a similar functional specialization in the striatum; that is, if we assume that functions are coupled to specific prefrontal corticostriatofugal pathways.

Although the general principle of functional heterogeneity associated with the topical input from the cerebral cortex has been demonstrated quite convincingly in physiological and behavioural studies (for references see above), the differential effects of striatal lesions involving the different projection fields of distinct prefrontal cortical areas have not been studied in detail.

B0t.h in the monkey (Rosvold, 68, 72) and in the rat (Dunnett and Iversen, 80, 81, 82a,b) the striatal target of the medial subdivision of the prefrontal cortex has been functionally differentiated from that of the orbital and lateral subdivisions.

Dunnett and Iversen found disturbed oral functions following lesions ventrolaterally in the caudate-putamen of the rat (see also Kelly et al., 88, 891, whereas, disturbances on delayed response tasks resulted from dorsomedial caudate-putamen lesions.

More detailed behavioural and pharmacological analyses of the prefrontal cortical areas and their related striatal sectors are required for a better understanding of the functions executed by the various basal ganglia-thalamocortical circuits that involve distinct parts of the prefrontal cortex.
In these analyses, the midline and intralaminar thalamic afferents and the inputs from other cortical areas to the same striatal sectors will also have to be taken into account.

The results of the present and previous tracing studies, in which the organizations of the thalamostriatal, thalamocortical, and prefrontal corticostriatal projections have been analyzed, provide an anatomical map that may facilitate future investigations.
